nexttext: where ${\bf R}_i$ and ${\bf P}_i$ denote the center of the position and momentum of the wave packet $i$, respectively, with the corresponding width $C_W$. Then the total wave function for the $N$-nucleon system is obtained by taking the direct product of single-nucleon wave functions
prevtext:
\title{Study of low density nuclear matter with quantum molecular dynamics:  the role of the symmetry energy}
 \author{Rana Nandi}
 \email[]{nandi@fias.uni-frankfurt.de}
 \affiliation{Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies, 60438 Frankfurt am Main, Germany}
 
 \author{Stefan Schramm}
  \email[]{schramm@fias.uni-frankfurt.de}
  \affiliation{Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies, 60438 Frankfurt am Main, Germany}
  
  \begin{abstract}
   We study the effect of isospin-dependent nuclear forces on the pasta phase in the inner crust of neutron stars.
   To this end we model the crust within the framework of quantum molecular dynamics (QMD). For maximizing
   the numerical performance, the newly developed code has been implemented on GPU processors.
   As a first application of the crust studies we investigate the dependence of the particular pasta phases on 
   the slope of the symmetry energy slope $L$. To isolate the effect of different values of $L$, we adopt an 
   established QMD Hamiltonian and extend it to include non-linear terms in the isospin-dependent interaction.
   The strengths of the isospin-dependent forces are used to adjust the asymmetry energy and slope of the matter.
   Our results indicate that in contrast to earlier studies the phase diagram of the pasta phase is not very
   sensitive to the value of $L$.   
   \end{abstract}

  
  \maketitle

\section{Introduction}
In the crust of neutron stars, at densities well below nuclear saturation density nuclei form 
crystalline structure embedded in an electron plasma in order to minimize the Coulomb energy. 
At higher densities, when nuclei are about to dissolve into uniform matter, 
various interesting spatial structures such as cylindrical and slab shaped nuclei and cylindrical and 
spherical bubbles etc., collectively called nuclear ``pasta'', may appear \cite{Ravenhall83,Hashimoto84}. 

The study of the pasta phase is very important for various astrophysical reasons. In core-collapse supernovae the  pasta phase
significantly affects neutrino transport through the matter, which plays a crucial role in the eventual supernova
explosion \cite{Horowitz04}. On the other hand electron-pasta scattering has a strong impact on the transport 
properties like electrical and thermal conductivities of the neutron star crustal matter. An enhanced electrical
resistivity due to the pasta structures could be a central effect to explain the decay of magnetic field in
neutron stars \cite{Pons13} and the thermal conductivity is essential to understand the cooling behaviour of 
neutron stars \cite{Newton13, Horowitz15}. The presence of the pasta phase might also be important to understand
the mechanism of pulsar glitches \cite{Lorenz93, Watanabe07}.

So far, a number of authors have studied the properties of the pasta phase. Most of the studies adopt static
methods such as liquid-drop models \cite{Lorenz93, Watanabe00}, Thomas-Fermi approximations
\cite{Oyamatsu93, Lassaut87} and the Hartee-Fock method \cite{Gogelein07, Newton09}. In these models few specific
shapes are assumed and free energies are calculated for all the shapes as a function of baryon density.
The  equilibrium shape at a particular density is then determined by minimizing the free energy. 
However, to study the formation and evolution of the pasta phase one needs to employ a dynamical approach that
allows for arbitrary nuclear shapes and can incorporate the thermal fluctuations on the nucleon distribution in 
a natural way. Furthermore, as the nuclear matter is a typical frustrated system with competing attractive
nuclear and repulsive Coulomb forces, many energetically competing structures might occur.
Only a few groups so far have adopted a dynamical approach.
The first study in this direction was done by Maruyama {\it et al} \cite{Maruyama98}, who developed a quantum
molecular dynamics (QMD) model to study the pasta phase. Later Watanabe {\it et al} adopted this QMD model and 
studied characteristics of the pasta at zero temperature \cite{Watanabe03} as well as finite temperatures
\cite{Watanabe04} and also the transition between different nuclear shapes \cite{Watanabe05, Watanabe09}.
Horowitz {\it et al} developed a semi-classical dynamic model (SMD) and studied various transport properties
\cite{Horowitz04,Horowitz05, Horowitz08, Horowitz09, Chugonov10, Horowitz15} as well as formation
\cite{Schneider13} and characteristics \cite{Schneider14} of the pasta phase. Recently, Dorso {\it et al}
\cite{Dorso12, Molinelli14} and Sch\"utrumpf {\it et al} \cite{Schuetrumpf13} studied the pasta phase using 
classical molecular dynamics (CMD) and a time-dependent Hartree-Fock approach, respectively.

The nuclear symmetry energy and its density dependence play crucial roles in both nuclear physics and astrophysics
\cite{Lattimer07,Li08}. Laboratory experiments constrain the symmetry energy at saturation density quite well
around $30\pm4$ MeV, but its slope $L$ at saturation is still very uncertain to lie in the range $20-120$ MeV
\cite{Zhang13}. The effect of different $L$ on the pasta phase of inner crust matter of neutron stars has
been studied within the liquid drop model
\cite{Bao14}  as well as the Thomas-Fermi approximation \cite{Oyamatsu07, Grill12, Bao15}. In all of these
calculations it was found that the width of the pasta phase decreases with increasing value of $L$. Sonoda
{\it et al} \cite{Sonoda08} used two different QMD models with different $L$ to study the pasta phase with proton
fraction $Y_p=0.3$ and found behaviour similar to the static calculations. But to understand the dependence of
the pasta phase on $L$ alone, one has to do such a study consistently within the same nuclear model approach. 
Therefore, in this article we study the dependence of the pasta phase on the slope parameter within a single QMD
model. The article is structured in the following way. After outlining the general formalism in Sec. II, we
present a careful parameter study of different strengths of the isospin forces in Sec. III. Finally, in Sec. IV we
draw conclusions and present an outlook of upcoming work in this direction.

\section{Formalism}
In QMD the state of a nucleon is represented by a Gaussian wave packet given as (we set $\hbar=c=1$)
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\psi({\bf r_{i}})=\frac{1}{(2\pi C_{W})^{3/4}}\exp\left[-\frac{({\bf r_{i}-R_{%
i}})^{2}}{4C_{W}}+i\,{\bf r\cdot P_{i}}\right]," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>𝐫</mi><mi>𝐢</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>W</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>𝐫</mi><mi>𝐢</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>𝐑</mi><mi>𝐢</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>W</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>i</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝐫</mi></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><msub><mi>𝐏</mi><mi>𝐢</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

Here we adopt an effective interaction developed by Maruyama {\it et al.} \cite{Maruyama98}, to simulate
the nuclear matter at sub-saturation densities. The Hamiltonian of the interaction has several terms:

prevtext:
Here we adopt an effective interaction developed by Maruyama {\it et al.} \cite{Maruyama98}, to simulate
the nuclear matter at sub-saturation densities. The Hamiltonian of the interaction has several terms:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\cal H}=T+V_{\rm Pauli}+V_{\rm Skyrme}+V_{\rm sym}+V_{\rm MD}+V_{\rm Coul}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℋ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>Pauli</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>Skyrme</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>sym</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>MD</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>Coul</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
whereas the single-nucleon densities are given by 
\begin{eqnarray}
  \rho_i({\bf r}) & = & \left| \psi_{i}({\bf r}) \right|^{2}
  = \frac{1}{(2\pi C_W)^{3/2}}\ \exp{\left[
                - \frac{({\bf r} - {\bf R}_i)^2}{2C_W} \right]}\ ,\quad \\
  \tilde{\rho_i}({\bf r}) & = &

\end{eqnarray}
with

with

}=\frac{1}{2}(1+\gamma)^{1/\gamma}\ C_{W}\ ." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>W</mi></msub></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mi>and</mi></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>W</mi></msub></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nuclear symmetry energy. The symmetry energy can then be expanded (to lowest order) around the normal nuclear density {$\rho_0$} as
where $\chi = (\rho-\rho_0)/3\rho_0$ denotes the deviation from $\rho_0$ and $L$ is the slope of the symmetry energy at {$\rho_0$} given by

where $e_0(\rho) = e(\rho,\delta=0)$ is the energy per nucleon of symmetric matter and $e_{\rm sym}(\rho)$ is the
nuclear symmetry energy. The symmetry energy can then be expanded (to lowest order) around the normal nuclear density {$\rho_0$} as

nexttext:
To evaluate $e_{\rm sym}(\rho_0)$ and $L$ we first choose a set of values for the parameters $C_s^{(1)}$ and $C_s^{(2)}$ and run our simulation 
for different values of $\delta$ (from 0 to 1), while keeping the density fixed at $\rho_0$ and switching off the Coulomb interaction.
Then we fit the obtained values of energy per nucleon with Eq. (\ref{epar2}) and get $e_{\rm sym}(\rho_0)$ as fit parameter (see Fig. \ref{f:fit1}).
Following the same procedure we also determine $e_{\rm sym}(0.9\rho_0)$ and $e_{\rm sym}(1.1\rho_0)$, which are then used to calculate $L$ as

{0}}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>sym</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>ρ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo fence="true" maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></msub></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

To evaluate $e_{\rm sym}(\rho_0)$ and $L$ we first choose a set of values for the parameters $C_s^{(1)}$ and $C_s^{(2)}$ and run our simulation

Following the same procedure we also determine $e_{\rm sym}(0.9\rho_0)$ and $e_{\rm sym}(1.1\rho_0)$, which are then used to calculate $L$ as

nexttext: The Euler characteristic can also be calculated from the topology of the structure as \cite{Michielsen01}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H={1\over 2}\int_{\partial K}(\kappa_{1}+\kappa_{2})dA\qquad\chi=\frac{1}{2\pi%
}\int_{\partial K}\kappa_{1}\cdot\kappa_{2}\,dA\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>κ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>κ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mi>χ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>κ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⋅</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>κ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>A</mi></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
To calculate the Minkowski functionals we first divide the simulation box in $64^3$ voxels and calculate densities at each voxel ($j$) as 
$\rho_j^{n,p} = \sum_i^N\rho_i^{n,p} $. We choose a density threshold ($\rho_{\rm th}$) and turn the density field into a
black-and-white data set according to
\begin{eqnarray}
 {\rm voxel}\ j &=& {\rm black\ if}\ \rho_j \geq \rho_{\rm th} \nonumber \\
        &=& {\rm white\ if}\ \rho_j < \rho_{\rm th}\,.
\end{eqnarray}
Then we apply the marching cube algorithm \cite{Lorensen87} to create a smooth polygonal surface representation of the black voxels.
Finally, the Minkowski functionals for the polygon are evaluated with the help of the Karambola package \cite{karambola}.

In order to investigate the dependence of the results on the choice of threshold, we repeat the procedure for a range of densities $\rho_{\rm th}$. In Fig. \ref{f:mf_th} we show
normalised Minkowski functionals $H/A$ and $\chi/V$ for various nucleon densities as functions of the threshold density. 
One can observe that $H/A$ increases slowly with $\rho_{\rm th}$, while the slope decreases with increased density. For $\chi/V$, we see
that a plateau region exists ($\sim 0.02-0.08$ fm$^{-3}$) that cover all reasonable values of $\rho_{\rm th}$. 
The width of this plateau decreases with density. For our analysis we take 
the average value across the plateau and evaluate the correspondong standard deviation for obtaining an error estimate.

\begin{figure}
 \centering
 \includegraphics[width=0.6\textwidth,angle=-90]{mf_th.pdf}
 \caption{Normalised mean curvature and Euler characteristic as functions of threshold density for various nucleon
 densities}
 \label{f:mf_th}
\end{figure}

Next, we compare the Minkowski functionals for three different values of the slope parameter $L$ at $Y_p=0.31$. In Fig. \ref{f:mf} we plot normalised mean curvatures as
well as the normalised Euler characteristics as functions of normalised density for three different $L$. Error bars indicate the standard 
deviation in the range of $\rho_{\rm th}$, where $\chi/V$ has a plateau (see Fig. \ref{f:mf_th}). It is evident from the figure that the
Minkowski functionals do not depend much on the value of $L$. This is in contradiction with earlier calculations \cite{Bao14,Oyamatsu07,Grill12,Bao15,Sonoda08}, where it was found
that the lower boundary of the pasta phase gets shifted to higher densities whereas the upper boundary is shifted to lower densities with
increasing $L$. The lower boundary is determined by the fission-like instability that increases with increasing volume fraction of the nuclear
region \cite{Oyamatsu07}. The volume fraction depends on $L$ through two competing factors. The first important factor is the 
saturation density, which for the asymmetric nuclear matter is given by \cite{Oyamatsu07}
prevtext: The Euler characteristic can also be calculated from the topology of the structure as \cite{Michielsen01}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\chi={\rm number\ of\ connected\ regions}+{\rm number\ of\ cavities}-{\rm
number%
\ of\ tunnels}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>χ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>number</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>of</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>connected</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>regions</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>number</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>of</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>cavities</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>number</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>of</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>tunnels</mi></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
To calculate the Minkowski functionals we first divide the simulation box in $64^3$ voxels and calculate densities at each voxel ($j$) as 
$\rho_j^{n,p} = \sum_i^N\rho_i^{n,p} $. We choose a density threshold ($\rho_{\rm th}$) and turn the density field into a
black-and-white data set according to
\begin{eqnarray}
 {\rm voxel}\ j &=& {\rm black\ if}\ \rho_j \geq \rho_{\rm th} \nonumber \\
        &=& {\rm white\ if}\ \rho_j < \rho_{\rm th}\,.
\end{eqnarray}
Then we apply the marching cube algorithm \cite{Lorensen87} to create a smooth polygonal surface representation of the black voxels.
Finally, the Minkowski functionals for the polygon are evaluated with the help of the Karambola package \cite{karambola}.

In order to investigate the dependence of the results on the choice of threshold, we repeat the procedure for a range of densities $\rho_{\rm th}$. In Fig. \ref{f:mf_th} we show
normalised Minkowski functionals $H/A$ and $\chi/V$ for various nucleon densities as functions of the threshold density. 
One can observe that $H/A$ increases slowly with $\rho_{\rm th}$, while the slope decreases with increased density. For $\chi/V$, we see
that a plateau region exists ($\sim 0.02-0.08$ fm$^{-3}$) that cover all reasonable values of $\rho_{\rm th}$. 
The width of this plateau decreases with density. For our analysis we take 
the average value across the plateau and evaluate the correspondong standard deviation for obtaining an error estimate.

\begin{figure}
 \centering
 \includegraphics[width=0.6\textwidth,angle=-90]{mf_th.pdf}
 \caption{Normalised mean curvature and Euler characteristic as functions of threshold density for various nucleon
 densities}
 \label{f:mf_th}
\end{figure}

Next, we compare the Minkowski functionals for three different values of the slope parameter $L$ at $Y_p=0.31$. In Fig. \ref{f:mf} we plot normalised mean curvatures as
well as the normalised Euler characteristics as functions of normalised density for three different $L$. Error bars indicate the standard 
deviation in the range of $\rho_{\rm th}$, where $\chi/V$ has a plateau (see Fig. \ref{f:mf_th}). It is evident from the figure that the
Minkowski functionals do not depend much on the value of $L$. This is in contradiction with earlier calculations \cite{Bao14,Oyamatsu07,Grill12,Bao15,Sonoda08}, where it was found
that the lower boundary of the pasta phase gets shifted to higher densities whereas the upper boundary is shifted to lower densities with
increasing $L$. The lower boundary is determined by the fission-like instability that increases with increasing volume fraction of the nuclear
region \cite{Oyamatsu07}. The volume fraction depends on $L$ through two competing factors. The first important factor is the 
saturation density, which for the asymmetric nuclear matter is given by \cite{Oyamatsu07}

\delta^{4}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>sym</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>sym</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

\Bigg{|}_{\rho=\rho_{0}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>L</mi><mrow><mi>sym</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>sym</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>ρ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo fence="true" maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
The resulting values are given in Table \ref{symparams4}. When we compare Table \ref{symparams4} with
Table \ref{symparams}, we see that the value of the symmetry energy $e_{\rm sym}(\rho_0)$ is no longer fixed 
around $\sim 34$ MeV, but varies in the range $\sim 25.0-32.2$ MeV. More interestingly, the values of
$L$ are now in opposite order for the same choices of parameters $C_s^{(1)}$ and $C_s^{(2)}$. If we now use
these values of $L$ and $L_{{\rm sym},4}$ to calculate the saturation densities as \cite{Chen09}

we get $0.838\rho_0$, $0.850\rho_0$ and $0.862\rho_0$ for Set I, II and III, respectively. These values of 
saturation densities are very close to the values obtained from our simulation and shown in Fig. \ref{f:rhosat}.
\begin{figure}
  \centering
   \includegraphics[width=0.4\textwidth, angle=-90]{rhosat_wtc.pdf} 
   \caption{Energy per particle as function of normalized density for $Y_p=0.31$ without Coulomb interaction. }
   \label{f:rhosat}
\end{figure}


\section{Summary and Conclusions}
We studied the inner crust of neutron stars within a quantum molecular dynamics approach.
Here, we investigated in particular the formation of pasta phases at densities close to the transition to
homogeneous matter. The interaction Hamiltonian was based on earlier work by \cite{Maruyama98}, where we extended
the isospin-dependent interactions to include non-linear terms in accordance with the isospin symmetric terms.
This allowed for a tuning of isospin-related features like the asymmetry and slope parameters while staying within
the same model approach. By determining the Euler characteristics of the simulated nucleon distributions we
studied the various pasta phases for different isospin forces. 

In contrast to previous molecular dynamics results \cite{Sonoda08} but in agreement with static model
calculations \cite{Oyamatsu07} the low-density onset of the pasta phase is quite insensitive to the slope 
parameter $L$. For the transition density from pasta phase to homogeneous
matter we have also not observed any significant dependence on $L$, unlike all previous calculations
\cite{Bao14, Oyamatsu07, Grill12, Bao15, Sonoda08}. As shown in the analysis of the simulation 
data, a careful fit of the results is necessary to distinguish the various expansion coefficients
of the isospin and density dependence of the energy of the system.

The numerical implementation of the simulation was done by making use of GPUs for the most time consuming parts 
of the calculation. With the computational framework in place, we will expand our simulations of the crust to 
study its transport properties.
